Well, it sort of worked, except there weren\'t enough struts on it. It only broke in half when I used Warp after landing, but the tilt was already there.

![vTrlq.png](http://i.imgur.com/vTrlq.png)
You have two sets pf 'pontoon fuselages' on the undersides of the hull; make a third set in the middle.
I\'ll try that, but I\'m fairly sure the lack of struts are the problem.
Then move the two sets closer together. The proximity of these fulcrum points will balance the forces pushing down of both sides, away from having the bulk of the weight straining the center.
I was thinking. Its funny how difficult it actually is to land anything on a carrier. How is anything, even a VTOL, going to land on your *Yamato*?
VTOLs, although it would lag way too much to get within 200m physics range.

> 
> VTOLs, although it would lag way too much to get within 200m physics range.

You\'re good at building things, yes, but I don\'t see how that transfers to controlability. Anything short of a flying bedstead, I couldn\'t imagine being able to put down on a deck so small. And a flying bedstead probably wouldn\'t have the range for it.
I didn\'t extend the deck because its width would get infront of the vertical stabilizers, but I could in sacrifice of design.

> 
> I didn\'t extend the deck because its width would get infront of the vertical stabilizers, but I could in sacrifice of design.

In which case, you might as well have put a gun there instead. Two runway parts is too short, and too thin.
